001package squidpony.squidgrid.mapping;
002
003
004import squidpony.ArrayTools;
005import squidpony.squidgrid.Direction;
006import squidpony.squidmath.Coord;
007import squidpony.squidmath.GWTRNG;
008import squidpony.squidmath.IRNG;
009import squidpony.squidmath.OrderedSet;
010
011/**
012 * A maze generator that can be configured using a {@link ChoosingMethod}, which can be customized for the app.
013 * Based in part on code from
014 * <a href="http://weblog.jamisbuck.org/2011/1/27/maze-generation-growing-tree-algorithm">Jamis Buck's blog</a>.
015 * This defaults to {@link #newest} for its ChoosingMethod, but {@link #random} is also good to try; you can specify a
016 * ChoosingMethod with {@link #generate(ChoosingMethod)}.
017 * @author Eben Howard - http://squidpony.com - howard@squidpony.com
018 */
019public class GrowingTreeMazeGenerator implements IDungeonGenerator {
020
021    private IRNG rng;
022    private int width, height;
023    public char[][] dungeon;
024    
025    public GrowingTreeMazeGenerator(int width, int height) {
026        this.width = width;
027        this.height = height;
028        rng = new GWTRNG();
029    }
030    public GrowingTreeMazeGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng) {
031        this.width = width;
032        this.height = height;
033        this.rng = rng;
034    }
035
036    /**
037     * Gets the most recently-produced dungeon as a 2D char array, usually produced by calling {@link #generate()} or
038     * some similar method present in a specific implementation. This normally passes a direct reference and not a copy,
039     * so you can normally modify the returned array to propagate changes back into this IDungeonGenerator.
040     *
041     * @return the most recently-produced dungeon/map as a 2D char array
042     */
043    @Override
044    public char[][] getDungeon() {
045        return dungeon;
046    }
047
048    /**
049     * Builds and returns a 2D char array maze by using {@link #newest} with {@link #generate(ChoosingMethod)}.
050     * 
051     * @return {@link #dungeon}, after filling it with a maze
052     */
053    @Override
054    public char[][] generate() {
055        return generate(newest);
056    }
057
058    /**
059     * Builds and returns a 2D char array maze using the provided chooser method object. The most maze-like dungeons
060     * use {@link #newest}, the least maze-like use {@link #oldest}, and the most jumbled use {@link #random} or a
061     * mix of others using {@link #mix(ChoosingMethod, double, ChoosingMethod, double)}.
062     * 
063     * @param choosing the callback object for making the split decision
064     * @return {@link #dungeon}, after filling it with a maze
065     */
066    public char[][] generate(ChoosingMethod choosing) {
067        if(dungeon == null || dungeon.length != width || dungeon[0].length != height)
068            dungeon = ArrayTools.fill('#', width, height);
069        else 
070            ArrayTools.fill(dungeon, '#');
071        
072        int x = rng.nextInt(width - 1) | 1;
073        int y = rng.nextInt(height - 1) | 1;
074        dungeon[x][y] = '.';
075        OrderedSet<Coord> deck = new OrderedSet<>();
076        deck.add(Coord.get(x, y));
077
078        Direction[] dirs = new Direction[4];
079        System.arraycopy(Direction.CARDINALS, 0, dirs, 0, 4);
080        OUTER:
081        while (!deck.isEmpty()) {
082            int i = choosing.chooseIndex(deck.size());
083            Coord p = deck.getAt(i);
084            rng.shuffleInPlace(dirs);
085
086            for (Direction dir : dirs) {
087                x = p.x + dir.deltaX * 2;
088                y = p.y + dir.deltaY * 2;
089                if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1) {
090                    if (dungeon[x][y] == '#' && deck.add(Coord.get(x, y))) {
091                        dungeon[x][y] = '.';
092                        dungeon[p.x + dir.deltaX][p.y + dir.deltaY] = '.';
093                        continue OUTER;
094                    }
095                }
096            }
097            
098            deck.remove(p);
099        }
100
101        return dungeon;
102    }
103
104    /**
105     * A way to configure how {@link #generate(ChoosingMethod)} places paths through the maze. Most often, you'll want
106     * to at least start with {@link #newest}, since it generates the most maze-like dungeons, and try the other
107     * predefined ChoosingMethods eventually. You can use {@link #mix(ChoosingMethod, double, ChoosingMethod, double)}
108     * to mix two ChoosingMethods, which can be a good way to add a little variety to a maze.
109     */
110    public interface ChoosingMethod {
111
112        /**
113         * Given the size to choose from, will return a single value smaller than the passed in value and greater than
114         * or equal to 0. The value chosen is dependent on the individual implementation.
115         *
116         * @param size the exclusive upper bound for results; always at least 1
117         * @return an int between 0 (inclusive) and {@code size} (exclusive)
118         */
119        int chooseIndex(int size);
120    }
121
122    /**
123     * Produces high-quality mazes that are very similar to those produced by a recursive back-tracking algorithm.
124     * <br>
125     * Example:
126     * <pre>
127     * ┌─────┬───────┬───┬─────────┬─────┬───┐
128     * │.....│.......│...│.........│.....│...│
129     * │.────┘.┌──.│.│.│.└───┐.┌──.│.──┐.│.│.│
130     * │.......│...│.│.│.....│.│...│...│.│.│.│
131     * │.──────┤.──┤.│.└─┬──.│.└─┐.└─┐.│.│.│.│
132     * │.......│...│.│...│...│...│...│.│.│.│.│
133     * ├─────┐.├──.│.└─┐.└─┐.├──.├─┐.│.│.│.│.│
134     * │.....│.│...│...│...│.│...│.│...│...│.│
135     * │.│.──┘.│.──┼───┼──.│.│.──┤.└───┼───┘.│
136     * │.│.....│...│...│...│.│...│.....│.....│
137     * │.└─┬───┴─┐.└─┐.│.┌─┘.│.│.└───┐.│.──┬─┤
138     * │...│.....│...│...│...│.│.....│.│...│.│
139     * ├──.│.┌──.│.──┴───┤.──┴─┤.──┐.│.└─┐.│.│
140     * │...│.│...│.......│.....│...│.│...│.│.│
141     * │.┌─┴─┘.│.├─┐.│.┌─┴───┐.├───┘.│.│.│.│.│
142     * │.│.....│.│.│.│.│.....│.│.....│.│.│.│.│
143     * │.│.┌───┘.│.│.└─┘.──┐.│.│.┌───┘.│.│.│.│
144     * │...│.......│.......│.....│.....│.....│
145     * └───┴───────┴───────┴─────┴─────┴─────┘
146     * </pre>
147     */
148    public final ChoosingMethod newest = new ChoosingMethod() {
149        @Override
150        public int chooseIndex(int size) {
151            return size - 1;
152        }
153    };
154    /**
155     * Produces mostly straight corridors that dead-end at the map's edge; probably only useful with
156     * {@link #mix(ChoosingMethod, double, ChoosingMethod, double)}.
157     * <br>
158     * Example:
159     * <pre>
160     * ┌─┬─┬─┬─┬─┬─┬─┬───────────────────────┐
161     * │.│.│.│.│.│.│.│.......................│
162     * │.│.│.│.│.│.│.│.──────────────────────┤
163     * │.│.│.│.│.│.│.│.......................│
164     * │.│.│.│.│.│.│.│.──────────────────────┤
165     * │.│.│.│.│.│.│.│.......................│
166     * │.│.│.│.│.│.│.│.──────────────────────┤
167     * │.........│.│.│.......................│
168     * ├────────.│.│.│.──────────────────────┤
169     * │.....................................│
170     * ├────────────.│.──────────────────────┤
171     * │.............│.......................│
172     * ├────────────.│.──────────────────────┤
173     * │.............│.......................│
174     * ├────────────.│.│.────────────────────┤
175     * │.............│.│.....................│
176     * ├────────.│.│.│.│.────────────────────┤
177     * │.........│.│.│.│.....................│
178     * └─────────┴─┴─┴─┴─────────────────────┘
179     * </pre>
180     */
181    public final ChoosingMethod oldest = new ChoosingMethod() {
182        @Override
183        public int chooseIndex(int size) {
184            return 0;
185        }
186    };
187    /**
188     * Produces chaotic, jumbled spans of corridors, often with dead-ends, that are similar to those produced by Prim's
189     * algorithm. This works well when mixed with {@link #newest} using
190     * {@link #mix(ChoosingMethod, double, ChoosingMethod, double)}, and not as well when mixed with {@link #oldest}.
191     * <br>
192     * Example:
193     * <pre>
194     * ┌─────────────┬───────────┬───────────┐
195     * │.............│...........│...........│
196     * ├─┬─┬─┬────.┌─┘.┌─┐.──┐.──┤.──┐.──┐.│.│
197     * │.│.│.│.....│...│.│...│...│...│...│.│.│
198     * │.│.│.└─┬──.│.┌─┘.└─┐.└─┬─┘.──┴───┤.│.│
199     * │.│.│...│...│.│.....│...│.........│.│.│
200     * │.│.└─┐.└─┐.│.│.┌─┬─┤.┌─┤.──┐.────┴─┼─┤
201     * │.....│...│.....│.│.│.│.│...│.......│.│
202     * ├────.├──.└──.──┘.│.└─┘.│.──┴─┐.│.──┘.│
203     * │.....│...........│...........│.│.....│
204     * ├────.└──.│.│.│.──┘.──────────┴─┴─┐.──┤
205     * │.........│.│.│...................│...│
206     * ├──────.│.│.│.│.────────────────┐.└─┬─┤
207     * │.......│.│.│.│.................│...│.│
208     * ├────.│.│.│.│.├─┬─┐.│.│.│.──┐.──┴───┘.│
209     * │.....│.│.│.│.│.│.│.│.│.│...│.........│
210     * │.┌──.├─┴─┴─┘.│.│.└─┴─┴─┴─┐.└─┐.│.│.│.│
211     * │.│...│...................│...│.│.│.│.│
212     * └─┴───┴───────────────────┴───┴─┴─┴─┴─┘
213     * </pre>
214     */
215    public final ChoosingMethod random = new ChoosingMethod() {
216        @Override
217        public int chooseIndex(int size) {
218            return rng.nextSignedInt(size);
219        }
220    };
221
222    /**
223     * Mixes two ChoosingMethod values, like {@link #newest} and {@link #random}, given a weight for each, and produces
224     * a new ChoosingMethod that randomly (respecting weight) picks one of those ChoosingMethods each time it is used.
225     * @param methodA the first ChoosingMethod to mix; must not be null
226     * @param chanceA the weight to favor choosing methodA
227     * @param methodB the second ChoosingMethod to mix; must not be null
228     * @param chanceB the weight to favor choosing methodB
229     * @return a ChoosingMethod that randomly picks between {@code methodA} and {@code methodB} each time it is used
230     */
231    public ChoosingMethod mix(final ChoosingMethod methodA, final double chanceA,
232                              final ChoosingMethod methodB, final double chanceB) {
233        final double a = Math.max(0.0, chanceA);
234        final double sum = a + Math.max(0.0, chanceB);
235        if(sum <= 0.0) return random;
236        return new ChoosingMethod() {
237            @Override
238            public int chooseIndex(int size) {
239                return rng.nextDouble(sum) < a ? methodA.chooseIndex(size) : methodB.chooseIndex(size);
240            }
241        };
242    }
243}
